elements.text: Checking in on this thread - I didn't see an acknowledgement on these, have they been added?

text: Why 2 IPs for a single validator ?

elements.text: Why 2 IPs for a single validator ?

text: It's to support multi AZ HA for our compliance

elements.text: It's to support multi AZ HA for our compliance

text: I understand that but can't private K8S clusters have a single outgoing IP ?

elements.text: I understand that but can't private K8S clusters have a single outgoing IP ?

text: I suppose you're on AWS

elements.text: I suppose you're on AWS

text: Likewise for us - we need at least 2 IPs for a cluster, and therefore a network. When using AWS EKS, the minimum NAT gateways, and therefore IPs it will assign is 2. There are ways to work around this with reverse proxies, but then that takes you quite a long route away from the setup instructions which - other than the multiple EIP issue - plays quite nicely with AWS EKS

elements.text: Likewise for us - we need at least 2 IPs for a cluster, and therefore a network. When using AWS EKS, the minimum NAT gateways, and therefore IPs it will assign is 2. There are ways to work around this with reverse proxies, but then that takes you quite a long route away from the setup instructions which - other than the multiple EIP issue - plays quite nicely with AWS EKS

text: Yes, we use AWS. Having NAT gateways across multiple AZs ensures that our workloads still have a route to the public internet if (in rare case) something happens to one of the AZs.

elements.text: Yes, we use AWS. Having NAT gateways across multiple AZs ensures that our workloads still have a route to the public internet if (in rare case) something happens to one of the AZs.

text:
One question on this one. I was able to set the schedule on the sv and since I had just one node, the vote was accepted. But did not see the domain pause after that schedule. Is the order of operations as follows
• SV create schedule and vote
• Once the schedule is hit, SV pause the domain
• That triggers the auto domain dump
or
• SV create schedule and vote
• When the time hits the schedule, domains should have paused on it own
• Domain dump happends on its own 
Would be grateful to get inputs on that.
Thanks

elements.text: One question on this one. I was able to set the schedule on the sv and since I had just one node, the vote was accepted. But did not see the domain pause after that schedule. Is the order of operations as follows
SV create schedule and vote
Once the schedule is hit, SV pause the domain
That triggers the auto domain dump
or
SV create schedule and vote
When the time hits the schedule, domains should have paused on it own
Domain dump happends on its own

Would be grateful to get inputs on that.
Thanks

text: Hi guys, we are getting Forbidden on devnet validator trying to scan a bunch of urls like this one: <https://scan.sv-2.dev.global.canton.network.cumberland.io/> all of a sudden. Any idea what could cause this?

all of a sudden. Any idea what could cause this?

text:
Our sponsor node (Canton’s sv-2) is giving us:

```<https://scan.sv-2.dev.global.canton.network.digitalasset.com>: curl: (22) The requested URL returned error: 503
jq: parse error: Invalid numeric literal at line 1, column 3```
Seems like with the sponsor not accepting requests the node stops syncing.

elements.text: Our sponsor node (Canton’s sv-2) is giving us:

: curl: (22) The requested URL returned error: 503
jq: parse error: Invalid numeric literal at line 1, column 3
Seems like with the sponsor not accepting requests the node stops syncing.

text: ~503 = forbidden, yup~

text: Forbidden is 403, 503 is "service unavailable"

text: Yup. Seems to be an issue with sponsor rather than our end as the rest are still serving requests.

root.text: Hi all - is it possible to migrate / recover CC balance from a non authenticated docker validator to a authenticated (-a) docker validator? if not, what are the options to migrate to authenticated validator but keep balances/users/cns, if any?

elements.text: Hi all - is it possible to migrate / recover CC balance from a non authenticated docker validator to a authenticated (-a) docker validator? if not, what are the options to migrate to authenticated validator but keep balances/users/cns, if any?

text:
Hello!
Has anyone gone through the process of migrating from non authenticated docker validator to a authenticated validator? The documents suggests <https://docs.dev.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_compose.html#configuring-authentication:~:text=If%20you%20have%20already,sh%20command%2C%20as%20follows%3A|wiping> the PostgresDB, is this safe on mainnet?

elements.text:
Hello!
Has anyone gone through the process of migrating from non authenticated docker validator to a authenticated validator? The documents suggests
wiping
the PostgresDB, is this safe on mainnet?

text: If they went from accepting traffic to refusing it, it's possible that something happened with their firewall configuration that wiped out your whitelisting. Could be something transient, but if it doesn't self-resolve I'd reach out to your sponsor to see if they can contact Cumberland about it.

elements.text: If they went from accepting traffic to refusing it, it's possible that something happened with their firewall configuration that wiped out your whitelisting. Could be something transient, but if it doesn't self-resolve I'd reach out to your sponsor to see if they can contact Cumberland about it.

text: (there might be a more appropriate person to reach out to, but since I don't know, I'd start with your sponsor)

elements.text: (there might be a more appropriate person to reach out to, but since I don't know, I'd start with your sponsor)
